div.p: ALLAN: People using stimulants like cocaine or methamphetamine --more commonally known as ice, meth or crystal meth-- often report feeling very confindent, which encourages taking unrealistic risks.

ALLAN: In addition research has found those driving under the influence of methamphetamine often drift out of there lane, drive erratically, and have high speed colissions that kill themselves or others.
ALLAN: Those coming down from a methamphetamine high are at high risk driving because they are frequently tired, very sleepy, and depressed. Making it harder to be alert.
ALLAN: Also methamphetamine is linked in the research with increased rates of death by homicide, suicide and drug overdose.

ALLAN: A person mixing cocaine with alcohol may initially fee less effect from the alcohol however cocaine leaves the body much more quickly than the alcohol leaving them suddenly very impaired from the alcohol.
ALLAN: This combination also has been found to increase violent thoughts, threats, and behaviors.
ALLAN: Any use of cocaine either alone or in combination with alcohol or marijuana increases the risk of crashes, driver fatalities, and other violent deaths.
ALLAN: Research has also found that those driving under the influence of MDMA also know as ecstasy are more likely to take unrealistic risks,
they are likely to have impaired thinking, coordination and ecstacy causes some drivers to speed or run red lights.
ALLAN: Some also experiance halucinations, obviously all of these increase risk for impaired driving, arrests, crashes, injuries and death.
